FacilityName: F. E. Weymouth Water Treatment Plant
ParentCompanyName: Metropolitan Water District of So. California

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California (MWD) distributes drinking water to member water agencies throughout Southern California.  MWD provides approximately 60 percent of the drinking water used by nearly 19 million people living on the southern California coastal plain between Ventura County and the Mexican border.

Disinfection is a critical process used by MWD in the treatment of its drinking water.  Disinfection helps to protect public health by killing pathogens in the water and preventing the spread of waterborne diseases.  The use of chlorine as a disinfectant in the treatment of drinking water and wastewater has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was introduced, around the beginning of the previous century.  MWD currently utilizes bulk chlorine for disinfection at all of its water treatment plants, including the F. E. Weymouth Water Treatment Plant (Weymouth Plant).

As one might expect from its superior disinfection properties, chlorine is a hazardous substance.  Thus, storing and handling chlorine can present a risk to employees and the public without proper precautions.  MWD regards safe practices in the storing and usage of chlorine to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with chlorine.  To further safe practices, MWD has constructed a Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility at Weymouth Plant to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected against accidental releases by chlorine vapor scrubbers.

Weymouth Plant's chlorine storage and usage process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program Rule (RMPR) and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulation.  Both of these regulations require submission of a Risk Management Plan (RMP).  An integral part of the RMP is a summary of policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility, including a description of the possib

le consequences in case of an accident and the actions, which will be taken, by the facility in an emergency. 



The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary: 

-Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.

-General facility and regulated substances information.

-Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

-Five-year accident history.

-Emergency response program summary.

-Planned changes to improve safety.



An updated RMP for the Weymouth Plant Chlorine Facility has been prepared and is being submitted to the EPA and Los Angeles County Fire Department in June 2015, to comply with the five-year RMP update requirement.  

The information required in the RMP Executive Summary is provided below for the chlorine containment and handling facility at Weymouth.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The MWD accidental release prevention policy for chlorine involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's RMP Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response.   The Weymouth Plant has an excellent safety record with chlorine use.



Facility and Regulated Substance Handled

The MWD F. E. Weymouth Water Treatment Plant (Weymouth) is located at 700 North Moreno Avenue, in La Verne, California.  The plant is situated just east of Interstate Highway 210 and south of State Highway 30, covering approximately 140 acres.  The plant was built in 1940 to treat drinking water, including disinfection with chlorine.  It is currently designed to process 520 million gallons of water a day (520 mgd).  The facility currently stores and uses chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the RMPR and CalARP Pro

gram rules, as well as the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (Cal/OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard.  

The Chlorine System at the Weymouth Plant is composed of the following components: (1) a totally contained chlorine feed system to receive, store, and deliver liquid chlorine to the process, evaporators, chlorine expansion vessels, associated piping and valving, leak sensors and monitors, and instrumentation, (2) totally contained evaporators to heat chlorine and convert it to gas for use in the process (evaporator units, associated piping, valves, and instrumentation), (3) totally contained chlorinators to regulate flow of chlorine gas under vacuum to the ejectors (chlorinator units, associated piping, valves, and instrumentation), (4) ejectors to mix the chlorine gas with service water and inject the resultant chlorine solution at application points throughout the plant, and (5) chlorine gas treatment system for capture and neutralization of an accidental chlorine release in the contained areas (packed column scrubbers, caustic storage, fans, pumps, and associated piping, valves and instrumentation).

The chlorine storage vessels (railcars) are totally contained in the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility storage bays.

The process flow for the Chlorine System begins at the liquid chlorine angle valves located on the storage vessels in each storage bay, which are connected by flexible metallic hose to the fixed piping system.  Liquid chlorine is transferred by its own pressure from the on-line storage vessel to one or more evaporators in the corresponding evaporator room.

Each evaporator uses an electrically heated water bath to vaporize the liquid chlorine.  The chlorinators regulate the flow of chlorine gas (under vacuum) through venturi eduction to the ejectors.  The ejectors are located at various points throughout the facility, and introduce chlorine (under vacuum) into service water to form a chlorine solution tha

t subsequently mixes with the water supply at different stages of the treatment process, for disinfection purposes.

The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is continuously monitored in the control room by video cameras and chlorine leak detectors.  Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the storage bays, evaporator room, chlorinator room and pipe tunnels.  Based on the concentration and location of chlorine detected, the leak detection system will activate a succession of safety measures, beginning with visual and audible alarms, then start-up of the chlorine neutralization system and shut down of the normal ventilation system, and finally, automatically closing the online storage vessel liquid chlorine angle valve.  The alarms are annunciated locally and at the chlorine alarm panel as well as at the operator's console in the control room.  Once alerted, fully trained personnel will assess the chlorine leak.  In addition, each chlorine storage vessel liquid angle valve connected to the process is provided with a remotely actuated (pneumatic) emergency shutoff system.  In case of a major chlorine leak, chlorine supply can be stopped almost instantaneously by actuating the shutoff system, automatically or manually from any of the three control panels: unloading platform, chlorine maintenance room, or control room.  Emergency showers and eye wash stations are also provided throughout the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, including the scrubber system.

A packed-bed chlorine gas scrubber system, consisting of two parallel scrubber units, is provided to neutralize an accidental release of chlorine gas from either chlorine storage bay, evaporator room, or the chlorinator room.  Caustic (~20% concentration) is used as the scrubbing media.  

The chlorine automatic shutoff system, pressure reducing valves, leak detectors, other detection and control devices, safety systems, and the computer control system are connected to an uninterruptible power supply (

UPS) system, which bridges the gap between when a power failure occurs and when emergency generators come online.  In the event power is lost at the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, an alarm will alert the control room.  The water treatment plant has an emergency generator system, which provides backup power to run the Chlorine System in the event of a power failure.  

The control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year round.  Access to the plant is through guarded security gates and the plant is patrolled by security guards.  The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is covered by video cameras and has door alarms, both of which are monitored from the control room.  Process storage areas are further secured with a badge entry system for authorized employees only.

Finally, no chlorine releases that caused (or could have caused) a safety or health hazard, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred at the Weymouth Plant during the last five years.  



Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Weymouth Plant accidental release prevention program complies with all RMPR, CalARP, and PSM requirements and is based on the following key elements:

-Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.

-Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.

-Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.

-Process hazard analyses of process, equipment, and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.

-Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

-Use of accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.

-High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff.

-Implementation of an incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.



Hazard-

specific prevention steps include a chlorine containment and scrubbing system to capture and neutralize an accidental chlorine release, availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, and shutoff device on the chlorine storage vessel that can be activated automatically or by remote control.  



Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine health and safety background information and SDS sheets.

Equipment safety information was meticulously compiled on the chlorine process.  Specifications for chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  Weymouth Plant also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information outdated.



Process Hazard Analysis 

In 1992, 1995, and 1998 detailed process hazard analyses (PHAs) were conducted for the chlorine system equipment and procedures.  The 1998 RMP PHA was further reviewed and updated in January 2004 as part of the five-year RMP Program update.  As part of the January 2004 PHA, a PHA was conducted for the chlorine containment and scrubber modification project (i.e., Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility design and construction).  This PHA was reviewed and revalidated in July 2009 and July 2014.  A list of recommended actions was developed in July 2009 and 2014 to further impro

ve chlorine safety. All of the 2009 PHA recommendations and all but one of the 2014 PHA recommendations have been closed.

A 5-year update of the January 2005 CalARP seismic risk assessment was completed for the modified chlorine facility in January 2010 and again in January 2015.  Based on Region 1 LEPC CalARP Seismic Update Guidance, recommendations were provided to Weymouth Plant staff for their evaluation and implementation.



Operating Procedures

The Weymouth Plant maintains up-to-date, accurate, written procedures that provide clear instructions for operating the chlorine process.  The Weymouth Plant ensures effective operating and maintenance practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the chlorine system.  The operating procedures include connection/disconnection for chlorine storage vessel, start-up and shutdown for chlorine evaporators, after maintenance start-up for chlorine evaporators, maintenance shutdown for chlorine evaporators, start-up and shutdown for ejectors, start-up and shutdown for chlorinators, startup and shutdown for chlorine scrubber, chlorine system emergency shutdown, start-up following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations.  Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations.  Weymouth Plant updates procedures at least annually, or whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Updated operating procedures will be developed and put in place prior to any new process equipment coming on line or changes made in the handling of chlorine equipment, and reconfiguration of the facilities.



Training 

Weymouth Plant employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine process are trained in an overview of the proce

ss and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  Weymouth Plant ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process, is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures pertaining to their duties.  Weymouth Plant training program includes four elements: (1) initial process and hazardous materials awareness training (2) refresher training, (3) documentation, and (4) testing.  Each employee presently involved in operating the chlorine process has been trained to safely carry out their duties and responsibilities as provided in the operating procedures.  

Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the covered process, to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, Weymouth Plant ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a change, as indicated in Management of Change and/or Pre Startup Safety Review documentation.

Weymouth Plant prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training, which includes the identity of the employee, the date and location of training, the signature of the person (s) administering the training and a copy of the test used to verify that the employee understood the training.



Contractors

Weymouth Plant has procedures and policies in place that ensure that contractors working in or near the chlorine process area are properly informed of the hazards, access limitations to this process area, its Emergency Action Plan, and are prepared to safely complete their work.  Weymouth Plant holds contractor safety briefings before allowing them near or in the chlorine process area; controls access to this process area, and evaluates the contractor's safety performance.



Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

Weymouth Plant ensures that a pre-startup safety review is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for

significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.

Weymouth Plant has a program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of process equipment.  Weymouth Plant mechanical integrity program includes the following:

-Written procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of process equipment. 

-Inspection and testing of process equipment, based on methods and frequency specified by equipment vendors, industry codes and practice, and/or prior operating experience.

-Detailed documentation of such inspections and tests on the process equipment.

-Training of personnel who will be maintaining the process in the mechanical integrity program procedures, an overview of the process and its hazards, and safe work practices applicable to their job tasks.



Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Weymouth Plant requires employees to employ safe work practices when performing "hot work" in, on, or around the covered process.  Weymouth Plant uses a permitting program to ensure hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near the chlorine process.

Weymouth Plant has developed and implemented procedures to manage changes (except "replacements in kind") that affect the chlorine process.  These procedures allow Weymouth Plant to identify and review any potential hazards and provide additional training, procedures and safety, process, or chemical information before the proposed change is installed and implemented.



Compliance Audits

Compliance audits are conducted every 3 years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  The Weymouth Plant assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The result

s of the audit are documented, and a plan is developed to resolve the audit's recommendations and suggestions. 



Incident Investigation

Weymouth Plant investigates all incidents that resulted in (or could reasonably have resulted in) a catastrophic chlorine release - a release that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.  If required, an investigation team is assembled and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented and findings and recommendations are resolved.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed with all affected staff.  There have been no such incidents involving the Weymouth Plant chlorine system in the past five (5) years.



The Five-year Accident History Summary

No chlorine releases that caused or could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Weymouth Plant during the last five years.



The Emergency Response Program Summary

MWD is currently a non-responding agency and, as such, does not have an emergency response plan.  Weymouth Plant has HAZWOPER-trained employees who will respond only to incidental chlorine releases.  Weymouth Plant also has employees trained to implement an Incident Command System.  If the accidental release requires an emergency response, external hazardous materials response agencies, such as the Los Angeles County Fire Department, will be called to handle a chlorine release.  Weymouth Plant coordinates with such local response agencies (Los Angeles County Fire Department and La Verne City Fire) to help ensure that they are familiar with the Weymouth Plant chlorine system and its emergency response requirements and that the chlorine system is reflected in their Area Plans.  Specially trained Weymouth Plant employees will be available during such a chlorine emergency to provide technical support t

o fire department responders.  

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were previously identified for the chlorine process in 1992, 1995, 1998 and 2004 Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) conducted for the chlorine facility that existed at that time.  These recommended actions were evaluated and implemented as required.   A PHA was conducted in January 2004 as part of the chlorine containment and scrubber modification project.  In July 2009 and July 2014 the PHA was reviewed and updated in routine 5-year updates.  The recommended actions to further improve the chlorine safety developed in these three CCHF PHAs have all been resolved.
